III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health Services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 4/14/23, youth broke their medical boot off when they were
angry. Youth has not been taken to replace the boot yet due to
youth's behaviors. Youth is supposed to wear the boot for an
additional 6 weeks. Additionally, staff member is not nice to youth,
but details are unknown.
Investigation On 04/27/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Youth A at
CFC. Youth A reported that he got mad and told staff he was
going to rip his boot off and throw it outside. He reported that he
does not remember who the staff was that was present at the
time, however stated that Youth B and Youth C were present.
Youth A reported he took of his boot and threw it outside. He
confirmed he was walking around on his foot. Youth A reported
another youth in his cabin (whom he could not remember the
name of) went outside and retrieved his boot for him. Youth A
reported he put the boot back on but indicated the velcro strap on
it was broken and he had to tie it up. Youth A stated it was around
shower time when he noticed his foot started to turn blue. He
reported he told Staff 4 and Staff 4 told him it was healing and
gave him some ice to put on his foot. Youth A reported he has
thrown the boot away because his foot is healed. He confirmed
he did not wear his boot all the time, but he was wearing it the day
before his doctor’s appointment. He also confirmed he was not
wearing the boot when he went to his doctor’s appointment
because he forgot to put it back on when he left the gym. Youth A
confirmed staff would remind him several times per day to put his
boot on. Youth A denied knowledge about missing any scheduled
2

doctor’s appointments relevant to the care of his foot. Youth A
also reported he did not have any specific reason for not wearing
his boot as prescribed by the doctor. He stated he likes to play
basketball and play in the gym and confirmed he would take it off
when he went to that area. Youth A reported his foot is healed
and feels “good”. He denied being in any pain at the time of the
meeting. Youth A also reported he gets along well with PM. He
denied that PM refused to help him with his boot and denied that
she is rude or mean to him or other youth. Another in-person
meeting was held with Youth A on 05/03/2023 at CFC. Youth A
was observed to be in a wheelchair and his foot had been placed
in another boot. He reported he had returned to the doctor and
got another boot for his foot. Youth A stated he had hit his
crutches on the bed frame and confirmed that he was being
aggressive with the crutches and trying to use them as a weapon,
so they were taken away and not given back. He also stated he
got angry and took his boot off, threw it on the ground and started
walking on his foot. Youth A was unable to indicate on what day
this occurred. Youth A advised that today while in a group
meeting, he became angry, punched the door and hurt his hand.
He reported he was taken to the doctor, and they stated it was
okay and told him to put ice on it.
On 04/27/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Youth B at
CFC. He does not recall being in the same unit as Youth A and
denied hearing him threaten to throw his boot. Youth B stated he
was in the unit with Youth A after his foot had healed and he no
longer needed the boot. Youth B confirmed he has seen Youth A
not wearing his boot over the last four weeks and also confirmed
he has heard various staff tell Youth A to put his boot on. Youth B
denied hearing staff be mean to Youth A and denied hearing PM
be mean to Youth A. He also denied PM has ever been mean to
him. Lastly, Youth B denied hearing or seeing Youth A request
staff assistance with his boot and they refused to provide it.
On 04/27/2023 an in-person interview was held with Youth C at
CFC. He reported seeing Youth A wear his boot, but not every
day. He denied being in the unit when Youth A threatened to
throw his boot out. He denied knowledge of any staff refusing to
assist Youth A with his boot. Youth C denied hearing or seeing
PM be mean or rude to Youth A. He also denied PM has been
mean or rude to him. He described PM as his favorite staff person
and says that she is like a mom. He further reported PM often has
a lot to do, so sometimes youth think she is being mean or rude
when she just cannot stop to talk with them. Youth C recalled he
only shared a unit with Youth A for one week while he was
3

wearing the boot, but thinks that Youth A had been wearing the
boot for about four weeks total.
On 04/27/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Supervisor 1
at CFC. He is a youth care worker supervisor at the agency.
Supervisor 1 reported he has witnessed Youth A refusing to put
his boot on when reminded by staff of the need to wear it. He
denied knowledge of Youth A not receiving assistance when he
asked staff to help him. Supervisor 1 also denied hearing or
seeing PM be rude to Youth A or any other youth in the program.
Supervisor 1 denied Youth A is currently on a safety plan. When
asked if Youth A reported pain in his foot what he would do,
Supervisor 1 replied that he would take him to the doctor.
On 04/27/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 3 at
CFC. She is a youth care worker at the agency. Staff 3 reported
Youth A is always refusing to wear his boot and all staff are
consistently reminding him to put it on. Staff 3 reported she has
attempted to encourage Youth A to wear his boot so that he does
not cause more damage. Staff 3 indicated when Youth A refuses
to wear his boot and does not respond to staff redirection, it is
documented in the staff logbook. Staff 3 denied she has heard
Youth A complain about any pain in his foot and denied that he is
currently on a safety plan. She further denied hearing or seeing
PM be rude or mean to Youth A or other youth at the facility.
On 05/03/2023 a telephone call was held with the complainant.
No additional information was provided.
On 05/03/2023 an in-person meeting was held with the Program
Manager (PM) at CFC. She confirmed Youth A went to the doctor
after the previous visit by the consultant on 4/27/23. Youth A had
reinjured his foot and it was placed back in a boot. PM reported
he was also assigned crutches to use, but they were taken from
him because he was attempting to use them as a weapon. Youth
A is now using a wheelchair. PM stated the use of the wheelchair
is going “okay”, but Youth A has to constantly be reminded not to
spin or attempt wheelies in the chair. PM reported the facility is
using 1:2 ratio to monitor Youth A. PM reported Youth A is still
taking off his boot, refuses to keep it on and has been walking on
his foot. PM advised Youth A will be going for a follow up
appointment with the doctor on May 4, 2023 and she is planning
to request a hard cast that he will not be able to remove on his
own. Another in-person meeting was held with PM at CFC on
05/05/2023. The DHHS specialist was also present. She
confirmed she has been employed with the agency since October
4

2022. PM advised she has disciplinary action in her HR file that
includes a write up for failing to report an incident. PM reported
the injury for Youth A originally occurred on 03/16/2023. Youth A
was skipping in the gym and obtained an injury. PM reported HDI
(on-call medical triage) was contacted, and Youth A was taken to
McLaren Caro on 03/17/2023. He was put into a medical boot for
his foot for 5 to 6 weeks. PM stated by 04/05/2023 Youth A had
damaged the boot and broke the velcro, but he was still able to
wear the boot. PM reported the medical administrative assistant
(Staff 8) was contacted and advised that an appointment was
needed for Youth A. PM reported she recieved a text message
from Staff 8 at approximately 1:38PM on 04/06/2023 confirming a
scheduled emergency appointment regarding his foot for 2:30 PM.
PM reported that when it was time to transport Youth A to the
appointment, he was being aggressive and it was determined that
it was not safe for him to be transported to his appointment. PM
denied an incident report was written based on behavior of Youth
A. She reported based on the policy; this incident did not meet
the criteria for a required completion of an incident report. Staff 8
was advised of the need to cancel the appointment; she contacted
the office and secured the next available appointment for
04/13/2023. PM reported when he went to appointment on
4/13/2023, Youth A was told that his foot was healed, and he no
longer needed to wear the boot. PM reported that she was aware
Youth A had complained to Case Manager (CM) on 4/27/23 that
his foot was hurting, and he was later seen at the hospital and
placed back in a boot. PM reported she supervised a zoom visit
between Youth A and his family on 4/14/2023. She did not recall
any concerns during the visit but recalled discussing the behaviors
of Youth A with the family. PM denied telling the aunt of Youth A
that his behaviors were unmanageable and denied talking down or
swearing at Youth A. PM denied that she has every stated “take
their shit away” or “they don’t deserve their shit” in relation to the
youth in the program. She denied she has been mean or rude to
the youth in the program. Lastly, PM reported CFC staff would
only call an ambulance to transport a youth to an appointment in
urgent or severe cases.
On 05/05/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 4 at
CFC. The DHHS specialist was also present. He is a youth care
worker who has been employed with the agency since March
2023. He reported he is assigned to work in various units. Staff 4
was unable to recall exactly how long Youth A has been in the
boot. He reported that he initially wore the boot all the time, but
after a couple of weeks began to wear it less. Staff 4 reported that
overtime the boot became very worn, and Youth A would be seen
5

walking on the boot and sliding his foot in a manner that would
cause damage to the structure of the boot. Staff 4 confirmed
Youth A was still wearing the boot, even though it was pretty worn
out. Staff 4 denied seeing Youth A “a lot” with the boot off. He
does not recall Youth A saying anything to him about his foot
hurting or looking blue during a shower. Staff 4 only recalled
providing Youth A ice for his foot when the injury first happened.
Staff 4 stated he encouraged Youth A to wear the boot so that it
would heal properly. He denied hearing or seeing PM speak to
Youth A in a rude or negative manner.
On 05/05/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 5 at
CFC. The DHHS specialist was also present. She recalled she
was in Unit 4 with Youth A on 04/06/2023. She stated she kept
asking Youth A to put his boot on and he stated that he was not
going to wear it because it was loose. Staff 5 stated she felt like
this was an excuse from Youth A as he would wear the boot
sometimes and when he was mad or didn’t feel like wearing it, he
would take it off. Staff 5 denied Youth A would complain of pain
and stated when he was not wearing the boot he would just wear
his flip flops. Staff 5 denied recalling Youth A being aggressive on
04/06/2023 and as a result not being able to go to a medical
appointment. Staff 5 denied knowledge of PM being mean or rude
to Youth A or any of the other Youth in the program.
On 05/05/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 6 at
CFC. The DHHS specialist was also present. She recalled Youth
A had been prescribed to be in the boot since the beginning of
April. She reported he did not wear the boot all the time and has
stated he does not want to miss playing basketball. Staff 6
reported Youth A has the boot “off” more than he has it “on”. She
denied he complains of pain and recalled he has specifically
stated that it does not hurt. Staff 6 reported she was working on
04/06/2023 and does not recall being advised of a medical
appointment that was scheduled for Youth A. Staff 6 recalled that
one day Youth A was kicking the trash can with his injured foot
and was directed to stop. Youth A said no and yelled “this is my
foot”. Staff 6 denied Youth A complained of pain when he was not
wearing the boot.
On 05/05/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Case Manager
(CM) at CFC. The DHHS specialist was present also. CM
reported he was supervising a visit with Youth A and his family
and after the meeting ended, Youth A told him that his foot was
hurting. Youth A then said that it was “ok” but that it hurt
sometimes when he plays. CM reported he advised Youth A to
6

complete a medical complaint, but still sent an email the next
morning (04/28/23) to the nurse about the concern expressed by
Youth A. He reported he did not complete the notification that
evening as it had slipped his mind. CM reported he was on
vacation on 4/28/23, but he still contacted the nurse. He denied
Youth A was walking weird on Monday or Tuesday of the week.
He recalled he saw Youth A playing with his adoption worker in
the conference room and he was walking on his foot. CM denied
seeing any incident reports written by staff that documented that
Youth A was not wearing his boot. Per CM, he reported he
“always” saw Youth A with his boot on. He denied he was told
that Youth A broke his boot or that he could not wear it any longer
because it was torn. CM denied being aware of PM being rude or
mean to Youth A or any other youth in the program.
On 05/05/2023 an in-person interview was completed with Staff 8
at CFC. The DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 8 works in
the capacity of medical administrative assistant. Staff 8 reported
on 04/05/23 she was contacted by PM and told that the boot of
Youth A was falling apart and needed to be addressed. Staff 8
reported she called the medical office on 4/5/23 and did not get an
answer. She called again on 4/6/23 and was able to confirm an
emergency appointment for him on the same day. Staff 8
reported she was later contacted by PM and told that Youth A
would not be able to make the appointment due to his behavior.
Staff 8 reported she called and rescheduled the appointment of
Youth A for 4/13/2023. She reported the office was only seeing
patients on Wednesdays and 4/13 was the next available
appointment. Staff 8 reported she would see Youth A playing
basketball and walking without his boot. She reported seeing him
without his boot on almost every day. She stated he was walking
fine and did not seem to be in any pain. Staff 8 further reported
after being advised that Youth A was reporting pain in his foot, on
4/28/23 he first went to urgent care where they stated it was not
broken and discharged him. Youth A continued to complain of
pain and on the same day was taken to the emergency
department, had an x-ray and it was determined that the foot had
been reinjured and Youth A was placed in a boot and told to follow
up with an orthopedic doctor. Staff 8 reported on 5/4/23 Youth A
had a follow up appointment with Dr. Bullet and he was changed
into a different style walking boot and remains in the boot at this
time.
On 05/08/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 9 at
CFC. The DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 9 denied she
was at work the day Youth A initially injured his foot. She returned
7

to work and saw he was wearing a boot. She reported Youth A
did not wear the boot as required and was more often out of the
boot than wearing the boot. Staff 9 reported she and other staff
would redirect youth to put his boot on and document his
unwillingness in the logbook. She reported Youth A is doing
better with the new boot but did play basketball this past weekend.
Staff 9 reported she believed that Youth A damaged the first two
boots by overly pulling the straps, walking on the boot and
throwing it around. Staff 9 denied recalling PM coming to talk to
her about an appointment for Youth A on 4/6/23 but confirmed that
he was acting up and being aggressive on this day. She denied
writing an incident report, but stated it was documented in the
logbook. Staff 9 denied hearing or seeing PM curse or yell at the
youth. She denied that youth have ever had anything negative to
say about PM to her and that all the youth “flock” to her.
On 05/25/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Clinical
Director (CD) at CFC. The DHHS specialist was also present.
CD became the therapist for Youth A in April 2023. She denied
he is on an active safety plan. She did, however confirm, there is
a safety plan in place regarding if he needs medical attention or
complains that his foot hurts, they will send him out immediately.
CD reported it is common behavior for Youth A to kick the wall
with his broken foot. She reported he has been keeping his
current walking boot on a lot more than his old one. She reported
that his previous boot was smaller, and it broke often. She said
he was still able to wear the broken boot without an issue. CD
wasn't sure what happened causing the boot to break, but thought
it had to do with Youth A taking the staples out of it. She denied
he ever complained to her that his foot hurt. CD denied he talks
about staff in their sessions and noted he gets easily irritated with
his peers. CD denied hearing or seeing PM be rude or mean to
youth in the program. She also reported the only time the agency
would have a youth transported to an appointment or the hospital
via ambulance is if they are suicidal, homicidal or need immediate
attention. She denied they would call an ambulance for a routine
medical appointment. She further reported that if a youth is being
unsafe, they will not transport them in a vehicle.
Documents Reviewed:
• Face Sheet for Youth A, Youth B and Youth C
• HR file of Program Manager - One written warning in file for
failure to report incident
• Medical Report dated 5/4/23. Indicated that Youth A was
being seen for “right foot injury”. Recommended that patient take
8

5000 IU Vitamin D daily for 2 months and prescription for fracture
boot. Patient discharged home with plan to follow up.
• Medical Report dated 5/1/23. Documented that Youth A was
seen for “hand pain” and discharged home with instructions to
take over the counter pain medication and treat hand with ice.
• Medical Report dated 4/28/23. Indicated that Youth A was
seen for “ankle pain” and discharged home with a “brace or boot”
with instructions to take Tylenol or Ibuprofen, apply ice and
elevate. He was also advised to follow up with orthopedic
physician.
• Medical Report dated 4/28/23. Indicated youth was seen for
“foot pain” and diagnosed with “closed nondisplaced fracture of
fifth metatarsal bone of right foot”. Patient provided with crutches,
postop shoe and splint. Patient was discharged home in stable
condition.
• Medical Report dated 4/13/23. Indicated patient being seen
for follow up for pain in right ankle. X-ray showed that fracture
had healed. Patient discharged home with instructions to follow
up as needed. It was also noted on the report that Youth A
arrived and was not wearing his boot.
• Various WHS-CFC Unit Shift Log Entries – Entries would
document occurrences when Youth A was not wearing his boot
and some instances when he refused redirection from staff to put
the boot on and wear it as prescribed.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, there was not sufficient
evidence to support non-compliance with licensing rule 400.4142.
Interviews of both staff and youth were completed and most
reported that the agency attempted to ensure Youth A was
consistently wearing his medical boot. It was also documented
that the agency took appropriate steps to obtain a follow up
medical appointment for the youth when his boot was found to be
damaged. Youth was unable to attend the first scheduled
appointment due to his behaviors creating a concern for safety,
however he was scheduled for and taken to the next available
appointment. Youth A and other youth at the facility also denied
PM is rude or mean to youth in the program.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
9

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
